title: Ticket #167: GitTrac: Diff fails for new files
description:
See [13632], observe that the HTML is busted.

Problem: /setup_diff claims:

"If you leave the above entry blank, the following command is used: GIT_DIR='%RP' git-diff --full-index -t -p -r '%V1' '%V2' -- '%F' 2>/dev/null"

Lies.

If the file is new (or probably deleted), it merrily passes an empty string as V1 (or probably V1 on deletion). This causes git-diff anguish and it complains, "fatal: bad revision ''" and trashes the HTML as a side effect. So in reality, for new (and probably deleted) files, GitTrac doesn't do anything at all. But, if you set the entry, it always calls it.

Fix:

Instead of calling 

  GIT_DIR='%RP' git diff --full-index -t -p -r '%V1' '%V2' -- '%F' | /scratch.2/gittrac/bin/diff2html.py 2>/dev/null

we should call a wrapper script that detects an empty V1 or V2 and instead just spits back something more useful. Perhaps a simple 

  <p>%F was added</p>

or 

  <p>%F was deleted</p>

Of course, if V1 and V2 are both present, call the above command as usual.
